title: How the economy evades every crisis
content: In the face of chaos, the global economy powers on. Since 2011 growth has continued at around 3% a year. During the worst of the euro crisis in 2012? Around 3%. What about 2016, the year Britain voted ...
resumen:
In 1940, British investors saw the stock market rise after Adolf Hitler’s troops invaded France, with British companies delivering real returns to shareholders of 100% by the end of hostilities.

Today, pundits talk of a “polycrisis” including the covid-19 pandemic, land war in Europe, energy shock, inflation, banking scares, a Chinese property bust, and trade war. One measure of global risk is 30% higher than its long-term average. Consumer-confidence surveys suggest that households are unusually pessimistic about the state of the economy, both in America and elsewhere.

Since 2011, growth has continued at around 3% a year. The exception was in 2020-21, during the pandemic, with annual GDP growth of 2%.

According to IMF data, this year just 5% of countries are on track for a recession, the least since 2007. Unemployment in the OECD club of rich countries is below 5% and close to a record low. In the first quarter of 2025 global corporate earnings rose by 7% year on year.

Over the past 15 years, as the polycrisis has built, American stocks have marched upwards. More than half the rich world’s stockmarkets are within 5% of their all-time high. Wall Street’s fear gauge, the VIX, an index of stockmarket volatility, is running below its long-term average.

American businesses especially exposed to tariffs, such as sporting-goods firms, are only mildly underperforming the broader market. Ukraine’s stockmarket has risen by a quarter this year.

Goldman Sachs produces two indices of “cross-strait” risks. According to the index built using newspaper articles, the strait has rarely been so dangerous. By contrast, the market-based index, derived from share prices, hardly seems bothered.

A paper by Dario Caldara and Matteo Iacoviello, both of the Federal Reserve, suggest that higher geopolitical risk “foreshadows” lower investment and employment. Hites Ahir and Davide Furceri of the IMF and Nicholas Bloom of Stanford University find that increases in uncertainty tend to be followed by “significant declines in output”.

Since 1990 uncertainty has hurt growth less than before.

Firms are better than ever at dealing with shocks, and governments offer their economies unprecedented levels of protection.

During the pandemic some commodities became a lot more expensive—but this was a consequence of an enormous surge in demand, rather than falling supply. In 2021 chipmakers shipped 1.2trn units, some 15% more than the year before.

According to the New York Fed’s supply-chain pressure index, bottlenecks have remained in line with the long-run average, even in the face of Mr Trump’s trade war.

Modern supply chains are resilient because they are professionally run. In America there are 95% more supply-chain managers than two decades ago.

Rick Rieder, chief investment officer for fixed-income markets at BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, says that a services economy is incredibly consistent. Since 1990, goods consumption in America has fallen on a quarter-on-quarter basis in 27 quarters. Spending on services, by contrast, has contracted in only 5 quarters.

Fast growth in American shale oil and gas production has made the world less dependent on both Russia and the Middle East. OPEC produced fewer than 33m barrels of oil a day last year, just 12% more than in 1973. The rest of the world produced 64m barrels of oil a day, a figure that has more than doubled since the oil shock of the 1970s. Oil intensity, defined as the amount consumed per unit of GDP, has dropped by around 60% since 1973.

Politicians in the rich world have become extreme fiscal activists. During the pandemic, they spent over 10% of GDP on rescue packages. In 2022, during the energy crisis, the average European government spent another 3% of GDP. In 2023, in the middle of a banking scare, America hugely expanded its deposit insurance. The average rich-country government now runs a fiscal deficit of over 4% of GDP. America’s federal government is on the hook for contingent liabilities worth more than five times the country’s GDP.

The OECD’s unemployment rate never exceeded 7% during the pandemic.

From 2000 to 2022, the number of emerging-market central banks targeting inflation rose from five to 34, as Gita Gopinath of the IMF has noted.

As a share of emerging-market GDP, excluding China, sovereign debt in default rose to 1.2% in 2023, up from 0.6% in 2019. In 1987 the volume of emerging-market debt in default hit 11.7% of GDP.

59 countries were under strain in 2024 by the IMF’s and World Bank’s count, a record high.

This year America will spend over 3% of GDP on debt service, more than on defence.

A Chinese invasion of Taiwan could destroy, pretty much overnight, the West’s supply of high-end semiconductors.

title: Vietnam’s US Tariff Deal: Strategic Lift or Supply Chain Liability?
content: The recent tariff agreement has calmed bilateral tensions between Hanoi and Washington, but new trade tensions could be in store.
resumen: Last week, the United States and Vietnam announced that they had reached a landmark tariff agreement: a 20 percent duty will apply to confirmed Vietnamese-origin goods, while transshipments from third countries through Vietnam will face a 40 percent levy. The deal marks a significant turning point in Vietnam’s delicate act of strategic hedging between the U.S. and China. It expands Vietnam’s position within the reconfigured global supply chain landscape, shaped by efforts to reduce overdependence on China. This latest tariff agreement must be seen in the broader context of Washington’s evolving approach to trade and economic security. The United States has intensified its efforts to reduce reliance on Chinese supply chains, especially in strategic sectors such as electronics, semiconductors, and clean energy. Vietnam, which emerged as a key alternative manufacturing hub during the initial China-U.S. trade war, now finds itself formally included in Washington’s economic realignment. This deal focuses on enforcement and traceability. Vietnam is expected to ensure that goods exported to the U.S. are genuinely produced in Vietnam, not merely assembled or rerouted products originating from China. For Vietnamese exporters, the implications of this are mixed. The 20 percent tariff applied to verified Vietnamese-origin goods does not significantly change the playing field for sectors that were already facing elevated U.S. tariffs. For other industries, especially those that had benefited from Most Favored Nation rates, generally range from 0-10 percent, the new tariff level introduces real cost pressures. Vietnam’s wooden furniture sector – its leading export category to the U.S. – which previously enjoyed tariffs of 0-8 percent, now faces a 20 percent levy. Similar concerns apply to lower-end electronics components, footwear, garments, and leather goods, which typically fell into lower tariff brackets. These changes will likely impact production planning, investment flows, and supply chain strategies, both for domestic firms and for foreign investors using Vietnam as a manufacturing base. Vietnam became more attractive to foreign investors after the onset of the first China-U.S. trade war in 2018. Nike now produces more than half of its footwear in Vietnam, while Adidas sources nearly 40 percent of its global output there. Foxconn, Apple’s key manufacturing partner, has expanded rapidly in Bac Giang province, announcing plans to build a $270 million plant in 2023. Intel operates one of its largest chip assembly and test facilities in Ho Chi Minh City, with a $1.5 billion investment footprint. However, most of these companies continue to source upstream components and raw materials from China. Vietnam serves as the final assembly point, not the origin of value-added manufacturing. Goods assembled in Vietnam but with significant Chinese content may be deemed transshipments and subject to 40 percent duties, unless clear origin traceability can be demonstrated. Foreign investors from South Korea, Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, China, and even the U.S. itself now face considerable uncertainties. The Vietnamese government is expected to strengthen customs oversight, implement reliable origin-verification protocols, and improve digital traceability systems to ensure export compliance with U.S. standards. Vietnam must coordinate across multiple layers of government as well as with private manufacturers and foreign investors operating within its borders. Vietnam must manage its close economic relationship with China. If Vietnam’s compliance is seen as limiting access for Chinese-linked products, Beijing may respond. Vietnam is now pressing for reciprocal concessions: in particular, for Washington to recognize Vietnam as a market economy and ease restrictions on high-tech exports. In 2019, the U.S. Treasury Department designated Vietnam a currency manipulator, citing efforts to suppress the value of the đong. Trump has repeatedly accused Vietnam of “taking advantage” of the U.S., and these concerns may re-emerge as scrutiny over trade surpluses intensifies. If U.S. trade policy becomes more protectionist, even compliant Vietnamese firms may face a more difficult operating environment.

title: Rusia sigue dispuesta a dialogar con Ucrania tras los comentarios de Trump
content: El lunes, Donald Trump dio a Rusia un ultimátum de 50 días para poner fin a su ofensiva en Ucrania, lanzada en 2022, o enfrentarse a severas sanciones ...
resumen:
El Kremlin aseguró el martes que sigue dispuesto a negociar con Ucrania, pero que necesita tiempo para responder a las "serias" declaraciones del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, que dio 50 días a Rusia para poner fin al conflicto y prometió armas a Kiev.

El lunes, Donald Trump dio a Rusia un ultimátum de 50 días para poner fin a su ofensiva en Ucrania, lanzada en 2022, o enfrentarse a severas sanciones.

También declaró que se enviaría a Ucrania material militar, pagado por los miembros europeos de la OTAN.

El portavoz del Kremlin, Dmitri Peskov, indicó que necesitan tiempo para analizar lo que se ha dicho en Washington y si, o cuándo, el presidente Putin lo considera necesario, comentará.

Dmitri Peskov afirmó que Rusia espera "propuestas de la parte ucraniana" para una tercera ronda de negociaciones, después de dos sesiones infructuosas en Estambul.

Donald Trump trata de presionar a Moscú y Kiev para que alcancen un acuerdo de paz.

Durante su campaña electoral, afirmó que podría poner fin al conflicto muy rápidamente, sin nunca explicar la manera en que lo haría.

Trump cambió de tono en las últimas semanas, mostrando su frustración.

Se declaró "decepcionado" por el presidente ruso, que ha rechazado las propuestas de alto el fuego en Ucrania.

El lunes en la Casa Blanca, junto al Secretario General de la OTAN, Mark Rutte, dijo: "Pensaba que tendríamos un acuerdo hace dos meses, pero parece que no se concreta".

Sin un acuerdo en un plazo de 50 días, Estados Unidos introducirá "aranceles secundarios", es decir, contra los aliados de Moscú, amenazó el Presidente estadounidense.

title: Comunicación social y ¿“sanciones” imperialistas?
content: “…mucho menos debemos ignorar que la seguridad de que el país no se destruya desde dentro demanda logros dirigidos a que el pueblo tenga el bienestar que merece”.
resumen: El texto aborda la relación entre la prensa cubana y las "sanciones" imperialistas, principalmente las impuestas por Estados Unidos. Se menciona la importancia de que la prensa cubana aborde los asuntos de interés nacional con iniciativa y valentía, sin esperar a que otros lo hagan, y de denunciar y combatir los males que atenten contra la marcha y la seguridad del país. Se critica la manipulación del lenguaje por parte de los enemigos de Cuba, como el uso de términos como "sanciones" y "terroristas". Se destaca el bloqueo a Cuba, decretado formalmente en 1962, como una herramienta de Estados Unidos para "sancionar" el afán de soberanía y justicia social de Cuba. Se menciona que el bloqueo no ha logrado su objetivo de derrocar la Revolución Cubana. Se cita a Fidel Castro, quien en 2005 afirmó que los imperialistas no podrían destruir a Cuba, sino que eso estaría solo en manos de los cubanos. Se enfatiza la necesidad de que la prensa cubana cultive y defienda la unidad de las fuerzas revolucionarias, denuncie y combata la corrupción, y promueva el bienestar del pueblo. Se mencionan las leyes aprobadas para garantizar la comunicación social eficaz y la transparencia necesaria. Se hace referencia al desmerengamiento del proyecto socialista en Europa como una lección para el mundo. El autor es Luis Toledo Sande, escritor, investigador y periodista cubano.

title: Trump amenaza: Fin de guerra Rusia-Ucrania en 50 días o aranceles
content: Washington, 14 jul (Prensa Latina) El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, amenazó hoy con aranceles del 100 por ciento a los países que comercien con Rusia si no hay un acuerdo de paz para ...
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, amenazó con aranceles del 100 por ciento a los países que comercien con Rusia si no hay un acuerdo de paz para finalizar la guerra con Ucrania en 50 días. Trump dijo: «Estamos muy, muy descontentos con ellos», sobre Rusia. «Y vamos a aplicar aranceles muy severos si no llegamos a un acuerdo en 50 días», subrayó desde la Casa Blanca junto al secretario general de la Organización del Tratado del Atlántico Norte (OTAN), Mark Rutte. «Vamos a aplicar aranceles secundarios si no llegamos a un acuerdo en 50 días. Es muy sencillo», declaró Trump en el Despacho Oval. Trump también afirmó que Estados Unidos ha llegado a un acuerdo para vender armas a los países de la OTAN, y Rutte sostuvo que esas naciones, a su vez, enviarán el equipamiento a Ucrania para reponer sus arsenales agotados. Trump declaró: «Hoy llegamos a un acuerdo: les enviaremos armas y ellos las pagarán». El senador Lindsey Graham está impulsando una legislación en la Cámara Alta que otorgaría al presidente Trump la capacidad de imponer aranceles de hasta el 500 por ciento a cualquier país que ayude a Rusia.

title: U.S.-China Trade Plummets From 18% To 6%: Trump Tariffs Or Trickery?
content: China accounted for 5.89% of all U.S. trade in May, its lowest percentage in decades. Trump’s tariffs or trade trickery? It’s hard to dispute it’s a remarkable shift.
resumen:
China accounted for 5.89% of all U.S. trade in May, its lowest monthly percentage in more than 23 years.
When Trump entered the White House in 2017, China accounted for 17.77% of all U.S. trade.
China is the United States’ third-ranked trade partner, far behind No. 1 Mexico (16.22%) and No. 2 Canada (12.53%).
In May, China's total was 7.41% of imports.
China once dominated U.S. imports of cell phones and related equipment, accounting for 44.71% of the total just last year. In April, for the first time in more than two decades, and now May, it ranked fourth, behind India, Vietnam and Thailand.
Comparing the first five months of 2025 to the first five months of 2018, U.S. imports from China are down 27.55% while U.S. imports from the world are up 47.29%.
U.S. exports to China are down 12.49% while U.S. exports to the world are up 30.24%.
For exports, that means a $3.03 billion decrease in the value of oil shipped to China, a $2.54 billion decline in passenger vehicles and a $688.03 million decline in the primary motor vehicle parts category.
On the import side, it means a decline of $12.86 billion in the cell phone and parts category, a $10.57 billion decline in computers. It means a decline of more than $2 billion in seats, TVs and computer monitors, and furniture and parts.
The U.S. deficit with China has fallen 29.37%.
The U.S. deficit with Mexico is up 121.08%.
The U.S. deficit with Canada is up 240.67%.
The U.S. deficit with South Korea is up 268.33%.
The U.S. deficit with Taiwan is up 385.39%.
The U.S. deficit with Vietnam is up 212.85%.

title: Chinese economy bucks looming trade war to post Q2 GDP growth of 5.2%
content: Looming U.S. tariffs, together with a real estate market slump feeding into weakening consumer confidence, saw China's GDP growth slow in the second quarter.

title: China’s economy grows by 5.3% in first half despite Trump’s trade war
content: A surge of exports from Chinese manufacturers supported the growth, as customers and producers alike took advantage of the U.S.-China trade war ceasefire.

title: Brasil advierte que aranceles de Trump podrían encarecer productos en EE.UU.
content: El vicepresidente de Brasil, Geraldo Alckmin, advirtió que los aranceles del 50% a los productos brasileños anunciados por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, "podrían encarecer" el costo ...
resumen:
El vicepresidente de Brasil, Geraldo Alckmin, advirtió que los aranceles del 50% a los productos brasileños anunciados por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, "podrían encarecer" el costo de vida en el país norteamericano.

La relación entre la mayor economía de América Latina y Estados Unidos atraviesa una crisis diplomática a causa de estas tasas aduaneras, que según Trump son en respuesta a una "caza de brujas" de la justicia brasileña contra el expresidente Jair Bolsonaro y a decisiones del supremo tribunal de ese país contra redes sociales estadounidenses.

Las tasas, que entrarían en vigor el 1 de agosto, "repercuten también en Estados Unidos ya que podrían encarecer los productos y la economía estadounidense", dijo Alckmin, tras un primer encuentro con el gremio industrial para discutir posibles medidas ante el anuncio de Trump.

Los fabricantes de maquinaria, los productores de acero, los ganaderos y los cultivadores de café, naranjas y otros rubros agrícolas estarían entre los sectores exportadores más afectados.

Los aranceles "también representan una oportunidad  (...) podemos generar oportunidades para más acuerdos comerciales", valoró el vicepresidente tras el encuentro en Brasilia.

Alckmin, sin embargo, reiteró que la prioridad del gobierno y los empresarios es "una negociación" con Washington para revertir los aranceles.

El presidente Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva decretó la creación de un comité interministerial para debatir los próximos pasos del gobierno en la crisis con Estados Unidos.

El comité deberá evaluar "contramedidas" como la "suspensión de concesiones comerciales, de inversiones y de obligaciones relativas a derechos de propiedad intelectual" contra países "que tengan un impacto negativo en la competitividad brasileña".

El decreto presidencial permite aplicar una ley promulgada por el legislativo en abril, cuando Trump anunció un arancel del 10% a los productos brasileños.

Lula ha advertido que Brasil puede actuar recíprocamente contra Estados Unidos, en un claro desafío a Trump, quien avisó que si lo hace el porcentaje de los aranceles subirá.

Para el 62,2% de los brasileños los aranceles anunciados por Trump son "injustificados", según una encuesta divulgada por las firmas Bloomberg y Atlas Intel este martes.

Estados Unidos es el tercer socio comercial del país después de China y la Unión Europea.

Durante su primer mandato (2017-2021), Trump tuvo una relación cercana con el entonces presidente Bolsonaro (2019-2022), quien enfrenta un juicio acusado de haber tratado de impedir la asunción de Lula en 2022.

La fiscalía pidió el martes a la corte suprema que condene por golpe de Estado y organización criminal armada al exmandatario ultraderechista, que podría recibir una pena de hasta 40 años de prisión.

title: MP Materials and Apple Forge Strategic $500M Agreement Amid U.S.-China Trade Tensions
content: MP Materials, operating the only U.S. rare earths mine, has secured a $500 million deal with Apple to produce magnets for iPhones and other tech products. This follows the U.S. Defense Department's ...
resumen: MP Materials has secured a $500 million deal with Apple to produce magnets for iPhones and other tech products. MP Materials manages the only American rare earths mine. The deal comes shortly after the U.S. Defense Department's $400 million investment in MP Materials. The Las Vegas-based company is now poised to expand its Texas factory to recycle materials for magnet production, with plans to start serving Apple's needs by 2027. Analyst Neha Mukherjee notes that the Pentagon's long-term price guarantee for key elements like neodymium ensures stable revenue for MP Materials.

title: Estados Unidos sube tarifa para visas no migratorias
content: Estados Unidos aprobó una nueva tarifa obligatoria de 250 dólares para quienes soliciten visas no migratorias. La medida entrará en vigor a partir de 2026 y se aplicará sin excepciones a quienes solic ...
resumen: Estados Unidos aprobó una nueva tarifa obligatoria de 250 dólares (aproximadamente 892 soles) para quienes soliciten visas no migratorias. La medida, firmada a inicios de julio, entrará en vigor a partir de 2026 y se aplicará sin excepciones a quienes soliciten visas de turismo, estudio o trabajo (B-1/B-2, F, J o M). Este nuevo cobro se sumará al costo actual de 185 dólares (alrededor de 660 soles), elevando el precio final a más de 400 dólares por solicitud, es decir, aproximadamente 1428 soles. Según las autoridades estadounidenses, el objetivo es reforzar la seguridad migratoria y cubrir los gastos de gestión. Las nuevas normas también impactarán a los solicitantes peruanos, quienes deberán asumir este incremento si planean viajar a Estados Unidos. Expertos advierten que el nuevo monto podría limitar la movilidad internacional de estudiantes, profesionales y turistas en países como el Perú. Esta medida forma parte de la denominada ley One Big Beautiful Bill, impulsada por Donald Trump, que incluye reformas fiscales, sanitarias y migratorias.

title: Inflation heats up in June as President Trump's tariffs start to bite
content: Clothing prices jumped by 1% in June, contributing to a rise in inflation during the month. Imported clothing is one area where the effects of tariffs are beginning to be felt by shoppers. Inflation ...
resumen:
Inflation picked up steam last month amid early signs that President Trump's tariffs are beginning to have an effect on the prices shoppers see in stores.

Consumer prices in June were up 2.7% from a year ago, according to a report Tuesday from the Labor Department.

Prices rose 0.3% between May and June.

Rising rents were the main driver of inflation in June. But the price of clothing, appliances and toys also jumped — which likely reflects the effects of import taxes. Clothing prices rose 0.4% while the price of appliances and toys jumped nearly 2%.

Energy and food costs were also higher in June, while the price of new and used cars and airline tickets was down.

The president has imposed tariffs of at least 10% on nearly everything the U.S. imports, with higher taxes on goods from China.

The government collected $27 billion from tariffs in June — a four-fold increase from the same month a year ago.

The average tariff on imported goods is now the highest it's been since the Great Depression.

Trump has threatened to impose even higher taxes on goods from many countries, beginning on Aug. 1.

Gasoline prices rebounded in June. And electricity costs jumped by 1%.

The uptick in inflation last month cements expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates steady when policymakers meet later this month, despite mounting pressure from the White House for lower rates.

President Trump has frequently attacked Fed chairman Jerome Powell and his colleagues for not cutting rates more aggressively.

Investors still think a rate cut is likely in September.

Clothing prices jumped by 1% in June.

Imported clothing is one area where the effects of tariffs are beginning to be felt by shoppers.

title: The tariff-driven inflation that economists feared begins to emerge
content: Inflation rose last month to its highest level in four months as the cost of gas, food, and groceries rose, reversing several months of cooling price pressures.

title: Trump’s Commerce Department imposes tariffs on tomatoes from Mexico, prices could soar
content: The U.S. Department of Commerce on Monday imposed an immediate 17.09% tariff on tomatoes imported into this country from Mexico. Most of the tomatoes sold in Arizona come from Mexico.
resumen: The U.S. Department of Commerce imposed a 17.09% tariff on tomatoes imported from Mexico. The new charge could add 10% or more to prices. Sen. Ruben Gallego cited a study suggesting that tomato prices could rise an average of 50%. The move ends the “Tomato Suspension Agreement,” first instituted in 1996. The Commerce Department concluded that Mexican companies were selling tomatoes in the United States at prices below what it costs to produce or below prices in their home markets. Gov. Katie Hobbs blamed the president. A study by Texas A & M University said that the tomato import trade directly and indirectly supports 50,000 jobs in the two states with $8.3 billion in economic impact. Mayor Jorge Maldonado said the decision will damage trade imports and have severe consequences for Nogales in revenue, employment and trade. Kimber Lanning, chief executive of Local First Arizona, said the policy will shift costs to Arizona small businesses, restaurants and grocers, which will raise prices, slow hiring and threaten livelihoods. Todd Sanders, president and CEO of the Greater Phoenix Chamber of Commerce, called the now-scrapped agreement “a model of fair trade, balancing access to Mexico’s ideal growing conditions with protections for U.S. growers and consumers.” Sen. Mark Kelly and Rep. Greg Stanton, and Republican Rep. David Schweikert wrote a letter in May to Lutnick urging him not to follow through with the tariff plan.

title: Strategies we can employ in tariff talks with the US
content: The United States has announced that as of August 1, 2025, it will impose an additional tariff of 35 percent on goods imported from Bangladesh. The US President Donald Trump has communicated this ...
resumen: The United States will impose an additional tariff of 35 percent on goods imported from Bangladesh, effective August 1, 2025. US President Donald Trump communicated this decision in a letter to the chief adviser of the interim government, Prof Muhammad Yunus, during ongoing Bangladesh-US tariff negotiations. The letter hinted at reconsideration if Bangladesh opens its markets to US goods and services. The announced tariff rate is lower than the originally announced 37 percent, but with the existing average tariff of 15 percent, the effective tariff rate will be 50 percent. The US is the single largest market for Bangladeshi goods, with $8.4 billion worth of goods exported in the 2024-25 fiscal year, representing 18 percent of total exports. About 2,377 manufacturing houses were associated with export to the US market. The tariff increase may put more than 800 exporting units under risk. In Bangladesh, over 87 percent of goods exports are RMG, with about 1,821 manufacturing units exporting these goods. Bangladesh has been earning over $4 billion from RMG exports annually since 2000, employing over four million workers, 80 percent of whom are women. Vietnam has only 20 percent tariffs on its goods. Five strands of thought can be synthesized: the government's approach, the private sector's involvement, the political dimensions, the importance of alliances, and the need for expertise in negotiations. Bangladesh should understand the US position, explore importing more US products, consider the US's political agenda, form alliances, and involve experts in international negotiations. Selim Jahan is the author.

title: Nvidia says Trump administration lifts ban on AI chip sales to China
content: Washington has been concerned China could use Nvidia’s chips to get a jump on the U.S. in high-tech fields, particularly when it comes to artificial intelligence.

title: From tariffs to universities, Trump’s negotiating style is often less dealmaking and more coercion
content: Trump recently summed up his approach when talking to reporters about trade talks with other countries. “They don’t set the deal," he said. "I set the deal.” ...
resumen:
President Trump's negotiating style is more ultimatum than compromise. He has used tariffs, pressure on the Federal Reserve, and investigations into higher education to exert influence. Trump's approach is seen by some as an attempt to bend others to his will, while critics fear he is eroding democratic foundations.

Trump has targeted Harvard University, terminating federal grants and attempting to block foreign students, while also threatening to revoke its tax-exempt status. Administration officials also pulled funding from the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia University. The University of Virginia's president resigned following a Justice Department investigation.

Trump has also faced criticism for his actions towards the Federal Reserve, including blaming Fed Chair Jerome Powell for not cutting interest rates fast enough. He has also called for Powell to resign.

Trump has used the threat of tariffs, including against the EU and Mexico, and has also used them to influence other countries' court systems.

title: Shares gain ahead of key US earnings and data, while trade talks loom
content: Shares climbed worldwide and the dollar held onto most of its July gains on Tuesday as market participants entered a key week for U.S. earnings, inflation data and trade talks in a relatively ...

title: Opinion: The nation needs new trade deals now
content: In this opinion piece, Neil Caskey, CEO of the National Corn Growers Association, says there are several key foreign markets ripe for trade deals that should be prioritized by the Trump administration ...
resumen: The decisions on trade that President Donald Trump makes over the coming days and weeks could be the most consequential in years for American citizens, the U.S. economy and the corn farmers. Farmers are eager to know what comes after July 9, the date when Trump’s pause on reciprocal tariffs ends. Resuming high tariffs on imports, and the threat of reciprocal tariffs placed on U.S. exports, creates economic uncertainty, while also damaging long-term relationships with our foreign partners. Following the 2018 trade war, China, the world’s largest agriculture export market, turned to other suppliers and began investing heavily in Brazil, our largest agriculture competitor. A renewed trade war only encourages continued movement away from the U.S. as a reliable global supplier. The administration needs to quickly focus on brokering new agreements. As sales of the 2024 corn crop year wrap up and the 2025 crop nears harvest, farmers are already facing increased costs of production and a lower valued corn crop due to falling corn price. The anticipated 2025 crop value is $2.4 billion lower than if valued at the 2024 average corn price and $5.5 billion lower than if valued at the 2023 average corn price. Lower corn production has a negative impact on rural communities and the national economy. The nation’s 300,000 corn farmers are ready to supply the world. Recent reports of trade missions, negotiations and new trade deals are incredibly welcomed – and desperately needed – for America’s farmers. The president recently secured a deal with the UK that could expand ethanol exports. Several other markets are ripe for a good deal. A framework with Vietnam is a positive start. Vietnam has rising disposable incomes, rapid rates of urbanization and changing dietary preferences, all of which increase demand for food and livestock production. The country’s demand for animal feed ingredients like corn and soybean meal is rapidly growing but only 20% of its need is being met with domestic production. Most of the country’s imported grain comes from South America, but a recent reduction in its tariff on U.S. corn shows the potential of a greater trading relationship if barriers are eliminated. India is another example of a country ripe for increased exports of both corn and products made from corn. If U.S. corn farmers and biofuel producers were able to supply India’s sustainable aviation fuel market, it would represent a $434 million opportunity in the first year of the relationship alone. Opportunity exists to bolster relationships with long-term trade partners like Canada, Mexico, Japan, and South Korea. America is an agricultural powerhouse. Neil Caskey is CEO of the National Corn Growers Association.

title: Más del 60 % de vecinos de Miami se oponen a las redadas migratorias del Gobierno de Trump
content: Miami (EE.UU.), 15 jul (EFE).- Más del 60 % de los residentes en Miami (Florida), está en desacuerdo con las redadas migratoria promovidas por la Administración Trump, lo que ha llevado a varios a ase ...
resumen:
Más del 60 % de los residentes en Miami (Florida) está en desacuerdo con las redadas migratorias promovidas por la Administración Trump, según una encuesta publicada este martes.

El sondeo, realizado por la Universidad de Suffolk, con sede en Boston, y el medio WSVN-TV 7, desvela que el 61 % de los encuestados en Miami piensa que las redadas del Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE, en inglés) han ido demasiado lejos.

El 59 % aseguró oponerse a la cancelación del Estatus de Protección Temporal (TPS) para Haití, que ordenó el Gobierno del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, y que favorece a más de medio millón de haitianos residentes en Estados Unidos.

El 52 % de los encuestados aseguró que las deportaciones recientes de venezolanos, cubanos y argentinos que vivían en Miami reducían su apoyo a Trump en el futuro.

Tres de cada diez personas que participaron en la encuesta dijeron que volverían a votar a Trump si las elecciones tuvieran lugar hoy, una cifra inferior al 36 % que aseguró haber votado por el republicano en los comicios del pasado noviembre.

En el apartado económico, el 41 % de los encuestados aseguró que la economía estaba peor bajo Trump, mientras que el 37 % aseguró que había mejorado con respecto al mandato de Joe Biden (2021-2025).

La encuesta fue realizada a 500 residentes de Miami mediante entrevistas telefónicas, con un margen de error aproximado del 4 %.

El Gobierno estatal inauguró este mes de julio, de la mano con el ICE, un centro de detención para migrantes conocido como 'Alligator Alcatraz' (Alcatraz caimán), situado al oeste de Miami en un humedal hábitat de caimanes y pitones.

title: Vicecanciller de Honduras en Bruselas para diálogo con UE
content: Han sido los aranceles del gobierno de Donald Trump el fiel de la balanza para avanzar en el diálogo ... están interesadas en invertir en este gran proyecto. El espejo de Haití para la cumbre UE-CELAC ...
resumen:
Gerardo Torres Zelaya, vice ministro de Asuntos Exteriores y Cooperación de Honduras, conversó en Bruselas con DW.

La migración está entre los compromisos adquiridos esta semana entre la Unión Europea (UE) y los seis países de Centroamérica.

Torres Zelaya dijo que va a haber mayor flujo de hondureños hacia Europa, sobre todo a España, porque las condiciones en Estados Unidos son cada vez más adversas.

Mencionó los impactos de la política Trump, los miles de millones para fortalecer ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement), las cien mil camas nuevas para centros de detención y Aligator Alcatraz como la gran cárcel para migrantes.

El primer diálogo político de un Acuerdo de Asociación entre la Unión Europea y los seis países centroamericanos se firmó hace doce años y se comenzó a negociar hace veinte.

En 2006 empezaron las negociaciones; pero el golpe de Estado en Honduras en 2009 llevó a una relentización. En 2013 se logró el acuerdo comercial. Honduras casi ha triplicado la exportación de productos a Europa. Es el único acuerdo comercial cuyo balance es favorable a Honduras. Honduras es el principal proveedor de café de Alemania.

El diálogo político y la cooperación estuvieron más de una década en un cajón.

Lo que pasó en Nicaragua en 2018, el fraude en Honduras en 2017, los temas de seguridad en El Salvador, los escándalos de corrupción en Guatemala hace seis años, complicó el diálogo.

Se marchaba la cooperación alemana, sueca, suiza, italiana.

En agosto de 2022, por primera vez después de siete años, todos los presidentes de Centroamérica se reunieron y volvieron a apostar por la cabal implementación del Acuerdo de Asociación.

Sobre Nicaragua pendían sanciones europeas, también sobre Guatemala; El Salvador había captado negativamente la atención por sus malas prácticas en derechos humanos.

El Acuerdo de Asociación tiene una cláusula democrática y de derechos humanos que prevé su suspensión en caso de graves incumplimientos.

Las medidas unilaterales de presión han dado pocos resultados. Ponerle sanciones a funcionarios de Nicaragua no ha cambiado mucho la situación. Honduras nunca recibió sanciones a pesar de que vinieron muchas veces buscar apoyo porque en Honduras pasaba lo que en Nicaragua y más.

Los 27 europeos y los seis centroamericanos subrayan su compromiso conjunto con la agenda 2030, con los objetivos de desarrollo y con principios de la Carta de Naciones Unidas.

Honduras está a tres semanas de que se anuncie la implementación de aranceles donde el piso mínimo es el diez por ciento; para su industria de partes automotrices, el 25%. Para Europa, un 30%.

Honduras y Centroamérica pueden tener en Europa una parte del mercado que se va a ver reducido en Estados Unidos.

La guerra en Ucrania y esa amenaza en la puerta de su casa, el multilateralismo puesto en cuestión y la necesidad de nuevos socios llevó a la creación del Global Gateway.

El Global Gateway, la agenda europea de inversión en desarrollo verde y sustentable en terceros países, consta como una de las tareas de la agenda conjunta. Bruselas anuncia inversión en el mercado eléctrico regional de Centroamérica.

Muchas empresas europeas están interesadas en invertir en este gran proyecto.

Centroamérica irá a la cumbre entre la Unión Europea y la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (CELAC) que tendrá lugar en Colombia en noviembre de 2025.

Honduras, que acaba de pasar la presidencia a Colombia, insiste en que el drama de Haití debe estar alto en la agenda de esa cumbre UE-CELAC.

Haití es sinónimo de las amenazas que penden sobre Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, también ahora sobre Costa Rica.

La lucha contra los carteles criminales, de tráfico de armas y de personas no tienen ideología ni banderas, los estados se nos pueden ir de las manos.

La falta voluntad para apoyar de verdad a ese país caribeño se basa, también, en un racismo histórico.

Si Europa lograra entender el problema de Haití como entiende el problema de Ucrania podría ser fácil ayudarla: capacidad de defensa, capacidad de desarrollo económico, capacidad de sostenibilidad, capacidad de fortalecimiento político.

title: El dólar global y las bolsas se mantienen estables en la previa de nuevos datos de inflación estadounidense
content: Los operadores aguardan señales del efecto de los aranceles de Trump en los precios. El petróleo se estabilizó tras la postergación de nuevas sanciones a Rusia.
resumen: El dólar global tocó un nuevo máximo de tres semanas y subía en las primeras horas del martes, luego de la publicación de datos de inflación de Estados Unidos, que registraron el primer efecto de los aranceles de Donald Trump y anotaron el segundo aumento mensual consecutivo.

title: Bolsa española sube el 0,19% tras la postura de la UE sobre los aranceles de Trump
content: El selectivo español abrió con pérdidas, en sintonía con el resto de plazas europeas, y mantuvo el tono negativo durante prácticamente toda la sesión.
resumen:
La Bolsa española ganó el 0,19 % este lunes y sostuvo los 14.000 puntos pese a la incertidumbre por la imposición de aranceles del 30 % a la Unión Europea (UE), ya que Europa no tomará represalias inmediatas y continuará negociando con Estados Unidos.

El principal índice del mercado español, el Ibex 35, subió 26,8 puntos, ese 0,19% y terminó de negociar en 14.036 enteros. En lo que va de año, incrementa sus avances al 21,05%.

De los grandes valores, la eléctrica Iberdrola ganó el 0,87%; Telefónica, el 0,67 %; el grupo financiero BBVA, el 0,5%; y Banco Santander, el 0,26 %. El gigante textil Inditex perdió el 1,57%, como la cuarta mayor caída del Ibex; y la petrolera Repsol se dejó el 0,89 %.

El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, impuso el pasado sábado aranceles del 30% a los productos procedentes de la UE a partir de agosto.

title: China’s Economy Grows Steadily Despite Trump’s Tariffs
content: Official figures showed modest growth in the second quarter as exports shifted to other countries and Beijing invested in manufacturing and infrastructure.
resumen:
China’s economy grew at a steady pace in the spring, bolstered by domestic investment in factories and big projects like high-speed rail lines and a continued flood of exports throughout the world.

In the second quarter of the year, from April through June, China’s economy grew 1.1 percent over the previous three months, the National Bureau of Statistics announced on Tuesday. If that pace continues, the economy will expand at an annual rate of about 4.1 percent — only slightly slower than the growth in the first three months of this year.

The report on China’s gross domestic product, or G.D.P., shows how the country’s manufacturing-focused economy has endured President Trump’s steep tariffs, which briefly reached 145 percent in late April and early May.

Trade data released on Monday showed that China’s exports to the United States began to rebound in June, after the countries reached a tariff truce in mid-May, but remain depressed.

China’s exports to other countries, however, have jumped, particularly goods sent to Southeast Asia — many of which are re-exported to the United States — and to Europe and Africa.

Retail sales in China fell slightly in June compared with May as the slow-motion crash of the housing market continued to weigh on consumer spending.

In the first three months of the year, the Chinese economy got a boost when many overseas buyers accelerated orders in anticipation of tariffs.

Factory investment is booming to meet export demand, even as a glut of capacity has driven prices for manufactured goods down sharply. Rapid construction of factories and high-speed rail lines has more than offset a plunge in real estate development, down 11.2 percent in the first half of this year.

Retail sales of consumer goods were down 0.16 percent in June from the previous month, although still up 4.8 percent from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said.

“Domestic effective demand is insufficient, and the foundation for economic recovery and growth needs to be further consolidated,” Sheng Laiyun, deputy director of the National Bureau of Statistics, said in a statement.

China has been working to encourage spending, including with an extensive subsidy program that began last year. Working through its national government and provincial officials, China has provided subsidies for households to buy electric cars, air-conditioners and other manufactured goods, especially to upgrade to more energy-efficient models.

Some city governments curtailed the program in June after running low on money.

China’s economy looked particularly strong during the second quarter by Beijing’s preferred measure, growing 5.2 percent from a year earlier.

The government’s target this year is for output to be “around 5 percent” higher than last year.

The Chinese economy faces two closely related problems: lackluster spending and a glut of goods.

Apartments, electric cars and many other big-ticket purchases are all becoming less costly.

China has responded by reducing interest rates sharply. Rates on Chinese bonds are the lowest in 11 years.

The real estate sector nonetheless remains in serious trouble. After stabilizing last autumn and winter, housing prices are falling again.

Pensions in China are already tiny — as little as $20 a month for rural residents — and the government said last week that they would rise only 2 percent this year.

title: Primera lista de principales temas del día de Prensa Latina
content: Las Comisiones Permanentes de la Asamblea Nacional del Poder Popular (Parlamento) continúan hoy el debate y análisis de temas medulares para la sociedad cubana, previo al inicio del quinto periodo de ...
resumen:
*   **CUBA:** Las Comisiones Permanentes de la Asamblea Nacional del Poder Popular (Parlamento) continúan hoy el debate y análisis de temas medulares para la sociedad cubana, previo al inicio del quinto periodo de sesiones de la X Legislatura.
*   **EEUU:** La base del movimiento MAGA de Donald Trump se resiente o, al menos, así parece, en medio de polémicas entre facciones rivales del presidente de Estados Unidos.
*   **MÉXICO:** Martín Esparza tomó posesión del cargo de secretario general del Sindicato Mexicano de Electricistas para el período 2025-2030, tras ser reelecto con el 96 por ciento de los votos válidos en el reciente proceso comicial.
*   **GUATEMALA:** La Policía Nacional Civil de Guatemala celebrará hoy 28 años de creada.
*   **HONDURAS:** Honduras acogerá a partir de hoy el XI Foro Regional de Alimentación Escolar para América Latina y el Caribe, organizado por el Programa Mundial de Alimentos de Naciones Unidas.
*   **ARGENTINA:** La oposición en la Cámara de Diputados de Argentina gestiona hoy una sesión en medio de la crisis de la Casa Rosada con los gobernadores, a fin de debatir proyectos que, de aprobarse, obligarían al presidente a más vetos.
*   **BOLIVIA:** El Tribunal Supremo Electoral alista hoy reuniones con las Fuerzas Armadas y la Policía Bolivianas para reforzar la logística de los comicios generales de agosto próximo, ante recientes amenazas.
*   **BRASIL:** El Gobierno de Brasil comienza hoy a sostener reuniones con empresarios de los sectores industrial y agrícola que exportan a Estados Unidos ante el anunciado aumento de aranceles hasta el 50 por ciento por el presidente Donald Trump.
*   **CHILE:** Cuando faltan hoy cuatro meses para las elecciones presidenciales en Chile, el escenario está abierto, aunque las encuestas reflejan la posibilidad de una segunda vuelta entre Jeannette Jara y José Antonio Kast.
*   **ECUADOR:** El Gobierno de Ecuador y el municipio de Quito ejecutan hoy acciones para disminuir el impacto de la crisis hídrica en la capital tras la rotura de una tubería clave debido a un deslizamiento de tierra.
*   **FAO-OCDE:** La Organización de las Naciones Unidas para la Alimentación y la Agricultura (FAO) presentó hoy de conjunto con la Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económicos (OCDE) las perspectivas agrícolas mundiales desde 2025 al año 2034.
*   **FRANCIA:** El primer ministro francés, François Bayrou, presentará hoy la hoja de ruta del presupuesto del Estado para 2026, marcado por la polémica ante el anuncio de que incluirá 40 mil millones de euros entre ahorros y recortes.
*   **RUSIA:** El ministro de Asuntos Exteriores de Rusia, Serguéi Lavrov, se reunió con el presidente de la República Popular China, Xi Jinping, en la ciudad de Tianjin.
*   **FILIPINAS:** Una de las abogadas de las familias de 34 hombres desaparecidos en 2021 en Filipinas aseguró hoy que el caso se investiga por posibles vínculos con los asesinatos extrajudiciales ordenados por el expresidente Rodrigo Duterte.
*   **MALASIA:** Malasia confirmó su apoyo a la Conferencia de Emergencia que ocurrirá en Colombia hoy y mañana para coordinar acciones legales y diplomáticas en respuesta a la terrible situación en Gaza.
*   **VIETNAM:** La ampliación de las relaciones diplomáticas y del número de socios estratégicos e integrales de Vietnam en los últimos cinco años fue resaltada hoy en esta capital por el primer ministro Pham Minh Chinh.
*   **ETIOPÍA:** El Servicio de Inmigración y Ciudadanía de Etiopía emprende una modernización integral para abordar las demandas nacionales y cumplir con los estándares internacionales, reveló una fuente oficial en un evento que sesiona hoy En Addis Abeba.
*   **ISRAEL:** El futuro político del primer ministro israelí, Benjamin Netanyahu, está hoy en la cuerda floja tras la decisión de dos partidos ultraortodoxos de abandonar la coalición derechista en el poder.
*   **PALESTINA:** El número de nacimientos en Gaza durante el primer semestre de 2025 alcanzó los 17 mil, un descenso de 41,4 por ciento en comparación con igual lapso de 2022, antes del conflicto, denunció hoy una fuente oficial palestina.
*   **SIRIA:** Aviones de combate del ejército israelí lanzaron hoy tres incursiones contra las fuerzas gubernamentales de Siria, en la provincia de Sweida, a unos 120 kilómetros al sur de Damasco.
*   **SUDÁN:** Rescatistas extrajeron casi 300 cadáveres de las ruinas de casas y establecimientos destruidos por ataques a ciudades del estado sudanés de Kordofán del Norte (sur) de las Fuerzas de Apoyo Rápido (RSF, inglés), reportó hoy una fuente independiente.
*   **ECONOMÍA:** El expresidente ruso y subjefe del Consejo de Seguridad nacional, Dmitri Medvédev, calificó de «teatro» la amenaza del mandatario estadounidense, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles secundarios a Rusia.
*   **CULTURA:** La Cineteca Nacional de México acoge a partir de hoy el ciclo Maestros del cine de terror japonés.
*   **CUBA:** El XV Encuentro Internacional Cuentos para una Añeja Ciudad comienza hoy en La Habana con la participación de narradores de México, Guatemala y Cuba.
*   **DEPORTE:** La edición 112 del Tour de Francia ofrece hoy a los ciclistas la primera de sus dos jornadas de descanso con un líder inesperado, el irlandés Ben Healy (EF Education–EasyPost).

title: Albanese, Xi meet in Beijing to boost China-Australia cooperation amid strategic tensions
content: Albanese’s visit to China comes as Beijing seeks to capitalise on US President Donald Trump’s sweeping trade tariffs by portraying itself as a steady and dependable partner ...
resumen:
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on Tuesday.
Albanese’s visit to China is his second since being elected prime minister in 2022.
China and Australia will maintain open discussion and seek areas of collaboration despite strategic competition in the Indo-Pacific region.
Australia’s economy relies mainly on exports to China, particularly iron ore for the steel sector.
Xi stated that China was eager to “promote further development in the China-Australia relationship.”
Albanese told reporters that a decade-old free trade deal with China, Australia’s largest trading partner, will be examined, and the two presidents agreed to possible new collaboration on decarbonisation.
Albanese addressed Australia’s worries about the Chinese navy’s conduct of short notice live fire drills in the Tasman Sea between Australia and New Zealand in February.
Xi answered that China “engages in exercises in the same way that Australia does.”
Xi underlined at the meeting that China and Australia should continue to strengthen strategic mutual confidence, establish a favourable economic environment for both sides, and “safeguard multilateralism and free trade” in the face of a complex global landscape.
Albanese stated that “Dialogue needs to be at the centre of our relationship.”
Albanese is set to meet with Chinese Premier Li Qiang later on Tuesday.
Australia has followed a “cooperate where we can, disagree where we must” China policy.
Albanese said he had raised the case of jailed Australian writer Yang Hengjun with Xi.
Australia’s exports to China span agriculture and energy but are dominated by iron ore, and Albanese has travelled with executives from mining giants Rio Tinto, BHP, and Fortescue, who met Chinese steel industry officials on Monday, at the start of the six-day visit.
Albanese is in Beijing at the midpoint of a weeklong trip to China that started in Shanghai, where government and business leaders from the two countries discussed deepening cooperation in tourism and reducing carbon emissions in iron ore mining and steel production.
From Beijing, he will travel to Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province, where he said he would focus on growing ties in medical technology and sports.

title: Trump’s tariffs are starting to hit consumers’ wallets: Inflation climbs to 2.7% in June
content: Economists viewed this data as the first clear sign that Washington’s trade war is starting to affect consumer prices ...
resumen:
The Consumer Price Index rose to 2.7% in June compared to the previous year. Core inflation was 2.9%. Both numbers matched analysts’ forecasts.
Furniture and household supplies rose by 1%, toys by 1.8%, and clothing by 0.4%. New car prices fell by 0.3%. Gasoline became 1% more expensive in June, and electricity also rose by 1%, while natural gas increased by 0.5%.
The Federal Reserve’s 2% price stability target is further away. The Fed’s monetary policy committee meets in a few weeks. Investors widely expect it to hold interest rates steady at their current level of 4.25%-4.50%.
Trump enjoys mocking the Fed chair as “Too Late Powell”. Powell is guaranteed to remain in office until May 2026.
The futures market strongly expects the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged at its July 30 meeting. It sees a 0.25 percentage point rate cut as the most likely outcome at the following meeting on September 17. There was a 97.5% probability of the former and a 59.9% probability of the latter.

title: Little evidence to suggest a U.S. trade deal can be reached without tariffs: Carney
content: A trade deal with the United States will likely include some tariffs, Prime Minister Mark Carney indicated on Tuesday ahead of a meeting with his cabinet. Carney told reporters he expects the trade ...
resumen:
A trade deal with the United States will likely include some tariffs, Prime Minister Mark Carney indicated on Tuesday ahead of a meeting with his cabinet.

Carney told reporters he expects the trade talks with the U.S. to “intensify” ahead of the Aug. 1 deadline to secure a new agreement, but then in French he said the evidence suggests President Donald Trump will not make any tariff-free deals.

Carney singled out work to make “stronger” auto, aluminum and copper sectors — all industries specifically targeted by American tariffs.

Carney scheduled the cabinet meeting last week after Trump sent a letter laying out his plan to levy 35 per cent tariffs on Canada on Aug. 1. It was held virtually.

Industry Minister Melanie Joly told reporters following the meeting that cabinet had “good and thorough” conversations on Canada-U.S. relations following the cabinet meeting at a press conference in Halifax.

The prime minister is also set to meet with Canada’s premiers next week.

Jean Simard, CEO of the Aluminum Association of Canada, said in an interview with The Canadian Press that it seems “more and more evident” that countries will have to pay some sort of tariff to deal with the U.S.

Trump outlined his 35 per cent tariff plan to Carney in a letter sent on July 10.

A White House official later said that new tariff won’t apply to goods that are compliant with the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement on trade.

About 38 per cent of Canada’s exports to the U.S. claimed preferential treatment under CUSMA, though the number that could apply for the exemption is much higher.

Carney and Trump agreed last month to work toward a new trade and security pact by July 21, but the U.S. president unilaterally pushed back the timeline to secure a deal.

Simard said the industry needs to see more short-term support “very soon”.

Canada is the largest supplier of steel and aluminum to the U.S. The metals sector has seen job losses and decreased orders since Trump imposed tariffs.

The trade deal with the U.K. includes a 10 per cent tariff on most goods, while the deal with Vietnam includes a 20 per cent tariff on Vietnamese goods and a 40 per cent levy on goods being shipped through the South Asian nation.

Trump said Monday that he saw the letters he sent to Canada, the European Union and Mexico about increased tariffs rates as “the deals.”

U.S. inflation rose to its highest level since February as Trump’s sweeping tariffs push up the cost of a range of goods including furniture, clothing and large appliances.

American consumer prices rose 2.7 per cent in June from a year earlier, the Labor Department said Tuesday, up from an annual increase of 2.4 per cent in May.

On a monthly basis, prices climbed 0.3 per cent from May to June, after rising just 0.1 per cent the previous month.

In Canada the annual pace of inflation accelerated to 1.9 per cent in June as consumers were paying more at car dealerships, Statistics Canada said Tuesday.

The June price hike is up from 1.7 per cent in May.

title: EU threatens countermeasures over US tariffs, Trump says he is open to talks
content: The European Union Monday accused the US of resisting efforts to strike a trade deal and warned of countermeasures if no agreement is reached to avoid.
resumen:
The European Union accused the US of resisting efforts to strike a trade deal and warned of countermeasures if no agreement is reached to avoid the tariffs President Donald Trump has threatened to impose starting on Aug 1.

Trump said he was open to further discussions with EU and other trading partners before new 30% tariffs kick in next month and that EU officials would be coming to the US for negotiations.

Trump said he would impose a 30% tariff on most imports from the EU and Mexico next month.

EU ministers appeared closer to striking back.

EU trade chief Maros Sefcovic said he believed there was "still a potential to continue the negotiations" but voiced frustration with Washington's failure to agree to a deal with its largest trading partner. He added EU member states agreed the 27-nation bloc would need to take countermeasures if the trade negotiations fail.

Italy's foreign minister Antonio Tajani said EU had already prepared a list of tariffs worth 21 billion euros ($24.5 billion) on US goods if they fail to reach a deal.

Mexican president Claudia Sheinbaum said she believed the two sides would reach a deal on security ahead of the Aug 1 deadline.

The White House has clarified the 30% tariffs on Mexico, would not apply to goods shipped under the USMCA trade agreement.

title: Would Europe Actually Retaliate Against Trump’s Tariffs?
content: European Union officials have drawn up plans to impose levies on American imports, but questions abound about whether they would go through with them.
resumen:
European Union officials have spent this week working to finalize a plan to retaliate against President Trump’s tariffs, laying the groundwork to hit more than $100 billion worth of American imports with levies if negotiations on a new trade deal fail.

In April, E.U. policymakers approved a plan to impose tariffs on 21 billion euros (nearly $25 billion) of American goods. But they abruptly suspended them in a show of good will when Mr. Trump pivoted at the last minute and paused some painful across-the-board tariffs.

Mr. Trump said on social media last week that he planned to impose 30 percent tariffs on the bloc starting on Aug. 1. After that announcement, E.U. officials chose to again delay that first batch of retaliatory tariffs — which had been suspended only through July 14 — to allow room for more talks.

E.U. trade officials are finishing up a second list of tariffs that would target an even longer list of American goods, one that amounts to €72 billion ($84 billion) of products that include Boeing airplanes and Kentucky bourbon. The list was sent to member states on Monday, said diplomats. National representatives have not yet voted on the list.

Lars Lokke Rasmussen, the Danish foreign minister, said on Monday: “If you want peace, you have to prepare for war, and I think that’s where we are.”

Maros Sefcovic, the E.U. trade commissioner, talked to Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, on Monday. He was expected to speak with Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative, on Tuesday.

Mr. Sefcovic has said that European ministers have become more adamant about striking back if a negotiated solution could not be reached.

Mr. Sefcovic said at a news conference in Brussels on Monday: “We have to protect the jobs, you have to protect the businesses.”

Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, said on Sunday: “We will continue to prepare further countermeasures so we are fully prepared.”

E.U. member states would still need to vote to approve the second set of proposed tariffs that would apply to €72 billion ($84 billion) worth of goods. The list initially covered €95 billion of products, but it was whittled down after feedback and lobbying.

Officials could consider using a new tool, the so-called anti-coercion instrument, to target big technology firms or other American service companies by imposing trade or investment restrictions on them.

Ms. von der Leyen said on Sunday, when asked about using the tool: “We are not there yet. This is very important. This is now the time for negotiations.”

Mr. Lokke Rasmussen, the Danish foreign minister, said: “I don’t think this is weakness. It’s a clear signal that we don’t want to escalate things.”

Mujtaba Rahman, managing director for Europe at the Eurasia Group, a political risk consultancy, said that things would have to go very badly — an across-the-board tariff rate of perhaps 15 percent, along with charges on sectors — for Europe to hit back.

Ignacio García Bercero, a former E.U. trade official who is now at Bruegel, an economic think tank, predicted: “A 30 percent tariff would be no choice but to retaliate.”

title: U.S. Inflation Accelerated in June as Trump’s Tariffs Pushed Up Prices
content: The June data still reflects only the initial impact of Mr. Trump’s global trade war. Economists expect price pressures to intensify over the coming months, especially if new tariffs the president has ...
resumen:
Inflation accelerated in June as President Trump’s tariffs started to leave a bigger imprint on the economy.

The Consumer Price Index rose 2.7 percent from a year earlier, the swiftest pace since February, data released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Tuesday.

That is slightly higher than expected and up from an annual pace of 2.4 percent in May.

“Core” inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy prices and is seen as a reliable gauge for underlying price pressures, also shifted higher. Those prices were up 2.9 percent from the same time last year.

Over the course of the month, prices rose 0.3 percent, a notable pickup from a 0.1 percent increase in May. Core prices rose 0.2 percent.

The June data still reflects only the initial impact of Mr. Trump’s global trade war. Prices of products most exposed to tariffs, like household furnishings, jumped 1 percent, significantly higher than the 0.3 rise last month. Prices for appliances, specifically, rose 1.9 percent, up from 0.8 percent. The apparel index increased 0.4 percent, snapping multiple months of declining prices.

Gasoline prices rose 1 percent in June, after falling 2.6 percent the previous month. Grocery prices also rose, ticking up 0.3 percent in June.

Economists expect price pressures to intensify over the coming months, especially if new tariffs the president has threatened against the European Union and a host of other countries in recent days are imposed on Aug. 1 as planned.

Stephen Juneau, an economist at Bank of America, said that tariffs have forced companies to choose between absorbing the costs of tariffs and cutting into their profits, or raising prices and risking the ire of customers.

Monthly changes in June:
*   Nonalcoholic beverages: +1.4%
*   Fuel oil: +1.3%
*   Gasoline (all types): +1.0%
*   Electricity: +1.0%
*   Fruits and vegetables: +0.9%
*   Hospital services: +0.7%
*   Piped utility gas service: +0.5%
*   Tobacco and smoking products: +0.5%
*   Food away from home: +0.4%
*   Apparel: +0.4%
*   All items: +0.3%
*   All items excluding food and energy: +0.2%
*   Rent of primary residence: +0.2%
*   Physicians’ services: +0.2%
*   Motor vehicle maintenance and repair: +0.2%
*   Medical care commodities: +0.1%
*   Alcoholic beverages: +0.1%
*   Motor vehicle insurance: +0.1%
*   Meats, poultry, fish and eggs: -0.1%
*   Airline fares: -0.2%
*   Cereals and bakery products: -0.3%
*   Dairy and related products: -0.3%
*   New vehicles: -0.7%
*   Used cars and trucks: -0.7%

The Federal Reserve saw the risks of a stagflationary outcome receding. Now, the risks may be rising again.

The higher probability of a “stagflationary scenario” for the U.S. economy, as a result of Mr. Trump’s new threats, would keep the Fed “frozen in place because they’re still trying to debate what’s going to happen with inflation.”

Kathy Jones, chief fixed-income strategist at Charles Schwab, said that the new tariffs are another blow to any hopes for a Fed rate cut in the near term.

The Fed’s next policy decision will be on July 30.

Mr. Trump has incessantly demanded that the Fed lower interest rates significantly and has taken to berating Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, on a nearly daily basis and has even gone so far as to call for him to resign.

Mr. Trump again called on the central bank to lower interest rates by three full percentage points, citing “very low inflation” on social media.

title: Trump Claims "Great" Trade Deal Reached with Indonesia After Talks with Prabowo
content: President Trump claims to have secured a trade deal with Indonesia after negotiating directly with President Prabowo Subianto.
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump claimed to have reached a trade deal with Indonesia after talks with Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto. He announced this through the social media platform Truth Social on Tuesday, July 15, 2025. Trump wrote via the @realDonaldTrump account: "Great deal, for everybody, just made with Indonesia. I dealt directly with their highly respected President. DETAILS TO FOLLOW!!!" Trump stopped short of unveiling further details. Last week, Trump announced a 32 percent import tariff on Indonesia. Trump also stated that Indonesia could be exempt from tariffs if it builds a factory in the U.S. Coordinating Minister for Economics Affairs Airlangga Hartarto departed for the U.S. to start negotiating with Trump's government. Haryo Limanseto, the Spokesperson of the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs, said Indonesia has nearly a month to make tariff deals despite Trump announcing that Indonesia's 32 percent tariff will take effect on August 1, 2025. The government has prepared two strategies to respond to Trump's tariffs: convincing the U.S. that Indonesia is a strategic trade partner and expanding trade cooperation with other partner countries. Tempo contacted Haryo for a response.

title: China's economy grows at a robust pace as trade truce eases pressure from US tariffs
content: China has reported that its economy slowed in the last quarter as President Donald Trump's trade war escalated, but it still expanded at a robust 5.2% pace.
resumen:
China's economy slowed slightly in the last quarter but still expanded at a robust 5.2% pace, the government said Tuesday. That compares with 5.4% annual growth in January-March. The government said Tuesday that in quarterly terms, the world’s second largest economy expanded by 1.1%. In the first half of the year, the Chinese economy grew at a 5.3% annual pace, the official data show. Investments in fixed assets such as factory equipment rose only 2.8% in the first half of the year, implying 2.9% annual growth in May and a mere 0.5% increase in June. The 5.2% growth rate overstates the pace of expansion by about 1.5 percentage points. Capital Economics' activity proxy shows growth in China's gross domestic product, or GDP, at less than 4% year-on-year in April and May, forecasting annual growth of 3.5% for full-year 2025.
China reported that its exports accelerated in June, rising 5.8% from a year earlier, up from a 4.8% increase in May. Production of high-tech products, vehicles and electrical machinery and equipment rose by about 10% or more from a year earlier. A reprieve on painfully high tariffs on Chinese exports to the United States prompted a rush of orders by companies and consumers as the two sides resumed trade talks. Chinese companies also have expanded exports to and offshore manufacturing in other countries such as Vietnam. The national economy maintained steady growth with good momentum, showcasing strong resilience and vitality. A 0.1% decline in consumer prices in the first half of 2025 showed continuing weakness in domestic demand. Falling property prices and slowing retail sales also are concerns. Chinese leaders have set a growth target of 5% for this year, in line with last year's growth. A resumption of U.S. tariffs of up to 245% if Washington and Beijing fail to meet an Aug. 12 deadline for a new trade deal could derail the recovery in exports.

title: Trump vs BRICS
content: Mr. Trump lashed out at BRICS as “anti-American” and threatened to impose an additional 10% tariffs on countries aligning with the policies of the grouping. “BRICS is not, in my opinion, a serious ...
resumen: The 17th BRICS summit was held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. U.S. President Donald Trump responded angrily after the grouping criticized his tariffs and condemned the U.S.-Israel’s attack on Iran. BRICS, which began as an economic acronym referring to Brazil, Russia, India and China (South Africa joined later), has evolved as the main institutional voice of the Global South. Last year, BRICS added five new members — Egypt, Ethiopia, the UAE, Iran and Indonesia. The summit took place just weeks after Iran, a member country, was attacked. The member countries showed unity on two issues — on Mr. Trump’s tariff threats and the attack on Iran. The group’s July 6 declaration raised “serious concerns” about the tariffs, which it said were “inconsistent with WTO rules”. The 10-member grouping also termed the strikes on Iran, which started on June 13 triggering the 12-day Israel-Iran war, “a violation of international law and the Charter of the United Nations”. Member countries also “expressed serious concern over any attacks against peaceful nuclear installations that are carried out in violation of international law and relevant resolutions of the International Atomic Energy Agency” and pledged to “remain seized of the matter”. Mr. Trump lashed out at BRICS as “anti-American” and threatened to impose an additional 10% tariffs on countries aligning with the policies of the grouping. The Trump administration has slapped 50% tariffs on Brazil and 30% tariffs on South Africa. Republican Senators plan to bring a Bill called the Sanctioning Russia Act of 2025 that seeks to place 500% tariffs on imports of oil and sanctioned Russian products, which would hurt Russia, as well as India and China. In January, immediately after he was sworn in for his second term, Mr. Trump called BRICS members “seemingly hostile countries.” He wrote that they will face 100% Tariffs if they create a new BRICS Currency, or back any other Currency to replace the U.S. Dollar. Mr. Trump’s irritation appears to stem from BRICS declarations in South Africa in 2023 and Russia in 2024, where members discussed a BRICS Cross-Border Payments Initiative. India has dismissed Mr. Trump’s criticism that BRICS is anti-American. In March 2025, External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar had said that India had no plans to replace the U.S. dollar. India remains committed to BRICS, which now represents about half the global population, around 40% of the global GDP and a quarter of global trade.

title: Aranceles del 30 prácticamente prohibirían comercio con EE. UU.; la UE advierte contramedidas
content: Sus declaraciones llegan luego de que el pasado sábado 12 de julio, el líder de la Casa Blanca anunciara aranceles del 30% para las UE, a partir del próximo 1 de agosto, tras semanas de negociaciones, ...
resumen: El jefe de Comercio de la UE, Maros Sefcovic, declaró el 14 de julio que los Estados miembros deberán adoptar contramedidas a EE. UU. si fallan las negociaciones comerciales, luego de que el presidente Donald Trump anunciara aranceles del 30% para esas naciones. Sefcovic remarcó que si no hay un revés en la medida, las nuevas tasas “prácticamente prohibirían” el comercio entre la UE y EE. UU. Bruselas advierte contramedidas a Estados Unidos, aunque señala que "aún existe potencial para continuar las negociaciones". El Comisario de Comercio de la Unión Europea, Maros Sefcovic, tras una reunión con los ministros de Economía del bloque de 27 países, remarcó esto el 14 de julio. La UE decidió posponer hasta el 1 de agosto los aranceles de represalia sobre 21.000 millones de euros en productos de EE. UU., que debían entrar en vigor a la medianoche de este lunes. Los ministros también debatirán ampliar los planes para una nueva ronda de contramedidas, dirigidas a 72.000 millones de euros en importaciones estadounidenses a la UE, según el diario británico 'The Guardian'. Sefcovic planea reunirse con sus homólogos estadounidenses para analizar la situación y subrayó que cualquier acuerdo, producto de las negociaciones en curso, debe ser aceptado por los miembros de la UE y el Parlamento Europeo. El pasado sábado 12 de julio, el líder de la Casa Blanca anunció aranceles del 30% para las UE, a partir del próximo 1 de agosto. Sefcovic señaló su decepción frente al anuncio del líder de la Casa Blanca del pasado sábado, ya que su equipo negociador creía haber estado cerca de un acuerdo. Ambas partes habían estado negociando un principio de acuerdo durante cuatro semanas antes del anuncio de Trump. El jefe de Comercio de la UE también destacó que las tasas de aduanas recientemente anunciadas por Trump “prácticamente prohibirían” el comercio entre la UE y EE. UU. Sefcovic señaló que ese porcentaje tendría un enorme impacto, haciendo “casi imposible” continuar el comercio transatlántico actual. El ministro de Asuntos Exteriores de Dinamarca, Lars Løkke Rasmussen, afirmó que Europa no desea una guerra comercial con Estados Unidos. Francia ha pedido que se aceleren los preparativos para las contramedidas y ha afirmado que la UE debería estar preparada para utilizar su "instrumento anticoerción". Alemania ha pedido una respuesta "pragmática", mientras que Italia ha advertido contra una guerra comercial. Los países de Europa central y oriental temen que las contramedidas puedan provocar la retirada del apoyo militar estadounidense en Europa.

title: Trump: "Desesperación por no perder el liderazgo como potencia mundial"
content: Las amenazas arancelarias de Trump hacia Rusia, los sistemas Patriots para Ucrania y pagados por Alemania y los fallecidos en Gaza son temas de interés para nuestros usuarios de esta semana.

title: Trump da 50 días a Rusia para frenar la guerra en Ucrania o enfrentará aranceles del 100%
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, lanzó este lunes 14 de julio de 2025 un ultimátum a Vladimir Putin: si Rusia no detiene la guerra en Ucrania en un plazo de 50 días, enfrentará aranceles ...
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, lanzó el 14 de julio de 2025 un ultimátum a Vladimir Putin: si Rusia no detiene la guerra en Ucrania en un plazo de 50 días, enfrentará aranceles de hasta el 100% sobre sus exportaciones, así como sanciones indirectas que golpearán a sus principales socios comerciales, como China, India y Turquía. Trump advirtió en una reunión en la Casa Blanca con el secretario general de la OTAN, Mark Rutte. Estados Unidos enviará, a través de la Alianza Atlántica, miles de millones de dólares en armamento a Ucrania, incluidos sistemas antimisiles Patriot, municiones y misiles de largo alcance. Trump aclaró que este acuerdo permitirá a Kiev reforzar sus defensas. Los nuevos aranceles también afectarán a los socios comerciales de Moscú. Rusia mantiene vínculos estrechos con China, su principal socio con cerca del 34% del comercio bilateral, seguido de India, Turquía y Bielorrusia. China ya respondió a las amenazas de Washington. Trump llegó a la Casa Blanca en enero de 2025. El presidente ucraniano, Volodimir Zelenski, confirmó haber conversado con Trump y agradeció el respaldo en materia de armamento. Según la OTAN, países como Alemania, Canadá, Países Bajos, Noruega, Suecia, Reino Unido, Dinamarca y Finlandia ya comprometieron nuevas compras para reforzar las defensas de Kiev.

title: Irlanda alerta sobre el impacto de los aranceles de Trump en el comercio entre EE.UU. y UE
content: EL NUEVO DIARIO, DUBLÍN.- El Gobierno irlandés advirtió este martes de que la imposición de aranceles del 30 % a las importaciones procedentes de la Unión Europea (UE) por parte de Estados Unidos ...
resumen: El Gobierno irlandés advirtió este martes que la imposición de aranceles del 30 % a las importaciones procedentes de la Unión Europea (UE) por parte de Estados Unidos impedirá que el comercio funcione entre los dos bloques tal y como lo hace ahora. El viceprimer ministro irlandés, Simón Harris, recordó hoy que hay una diferencia «significativa» entre los aranceles del 10 % previstos inicialmente por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, y los del 30 % anunciados el pasado viernes. Harris señaló que unos aranceles de ese nivel no solo perturbarían el comercio, sino que en muchos sentidos impedirían que el comercio tal como lo conocemos funcione entre Europa y Estados Unidos. El ‘número dos’ del Ejecutivo de Dublín, de coalición entre centristas y democristianos, sostuvo que aún ve posible negociar un acuerdo con Washington, pero apuntó que «uno de los grandes desafíos» ahora es hacer frente a la «constante de volatilidad e incertidumbre» que está provocando la política económica de Trump. Harris declaró que en las próximas horas y días debe haber un esfuerzo renovado para alcanzar un pacto que proteja los empleos y la estabilidad económica en Irlanda, en Europa y en Estados Unidos. El vice primer ministro insistió en que hay que ser «claros y honestos» para reconocer que «afrontamos un momento de gran desafío económico», aunque también opinó que las amenazas arancelarias de Trump podrían ser una estrategia para presionar a otros países para cerrar acuerdos comerciales.

title: Nuevos episodios en la guerra comercial global
content: Todo esto no debiera sorprendernos porque el presidente Trump quiere aislar a Estados Unidos. El pequeño gran problema es que quiere obtener los beneficios de la globalización encerrándose tras un mur ...
resumen:
El presidente Trump quiere aislar a Estados Unidos. Quiere obtener los beneficios de la globalización encerrándose tras un muro y eso no es posible.

La guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China ha derivado en medidas y contramedidas.

En su primera administración, Trump inició la guerra comercial, elevando los aranceles para manufacturas chinas y estableciendo prohibiciones a empresas con tecnología estadounidense. Estas medidas respondieron al temor norteamericano de quedar superados por China en el liderazgo científico y tecnológico.

El advenimiento de Biden no cambió la situación, porque se ha instalado un consenso bipartidista de que China constituye la principal amenaza para Estados Unidos.

En su segundo mandato, Trump ha extendido la guerra comercial a prácticamente todo el mundo. El 2 de abril de este año, anunció aranceles para todo el mundo: una tasa de 10% para todos los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos y aranceles de hasta 50% para ciertos bienes y países.

China replicó en la misma medida, lo que llevó a una escalada de alzas, terminando nominalmente en más de 100% de arancel.

El Gobierno estadounidense reculó en buena parte de sus medidas, aunque mantuvo la posibilidad de aplicarlas si aquellos países con los cuales Estados Unidos tiene déficit comercial no ofrecían alguna compensación.

No cambiaron los aranceles altos para el acero y el aluminio. En los últimos días agregó al cobre, con un arancel anunciado de 50% a partir del 1 de agosto para el cobre refinado.

Estados Unidos no tiene suficiente producción local de cobre, por lo que no puede privarse de este metal estratégico para la electromovilidad y la industria militar.

Chile es el principal proveedor de cátodos de cobre refinado para Estados Unidos, que importa cerca del 60% de sus necesidades cupríferas desde Chile. En 2024, las exportaciones chilenas de cobre a EE.UU. alcanzaron los USD 5.634 millones, lo que representa el 11,1% del total de las exportaciones de cobre de Chile.

La propuesta de Trump de aumentar los aranceles al cobre en un 50% podría alterar la demanda estadounidense y reordenar el comercio del cobre.

El mayor costo del cobre, además de impulsar la inflación en EE.UU., podría afectar su eficiencia productiva. Los países asiáticos, principalmente China, podrían ganar competitividad.

Los mercados reaccionan cada vez menos a los anuncios de Trump, internalizando el efecto bluff, aunque siempre se mantiene la incertidumbre, porque EE.UU. tiene la capacidad de imponer más altas tasas.

Estados Unidos es uno de los compradores importantes en el mundo, por lo cual tiene la posibilidad de afectar a quienes le venden.

El problema de Trump es que está peleando con todos a la vez.

La Unión Europea, Canadá, México, China y otros países asiáticos podrían aunar posiciones y no solo elevar el costo a pagar por la economía estadounidense, sino redireccionar el comercio y las inversiones en desmedro de ese país.

La economía estadounidense se verá afectada con el resurgimiento de la inflación y menor empleo. También el capital reputacional y la influencia de Estados Unidos se está erosionando.
